newsitem.title: CHINA: Shanghai copper ends up on LME gains.
newsitem.headline: Shanghai copper ends up on LME gains.

text.p: Shanghai copper futures ended up on Tuesday due to overnight gains on the London Metal Exchange, traders said.
The most active February 1997 contract ended at 19,180 yuan ($2,310) per tonne, rising 270 yuan. It opened at 19,000 yuan, hitting and intra-day low of 18,950 and a high of 19,190.
November rose 180 to 18,860 yuan, December 260 to 18,880, January 270 to 19,100, March 200 to 19,200 and April 100 to 19,200.
Combined volume fell to 63,880 tonnes from 65,400.
Copper opened higher and rose further before most contracts closed near their intra-day highs.
Traders said LME gains encouraged long position holders and short-covering pushed copper up for most of the session.
"Much of the short-covering came from retail investors who are wary about the future trend in the short term," one trader said.
"LME copper did not breach the $1,970 resistance level despite declines of stockpiles, which indicates the long- and mid-term downward trend may not change," he added.
Traders said rebounds over the past two days had not changed the short-term weak market sentiment in Shanghai based on the over-supply of domestic spot copper.
"The thin volume indicates investors lack confidence in the future trend," a second trader said.
Analysts expect copper to meet strong resistance at the 19,500 yuan level in the next few days.
Aluminium ended down. November fell 110 to 13,380 yuan per tonne, December 200 to 13,200 and January 200 to 13,200.
Combined volume rose to 1,350 tonnes from 620.
